newsitem.title: GERMANY: Porsche profit triples after early 1990s woes.
newsitem.headline: Porsche profit triples after early 1990s woes.

text.p: Porsche AG said Friday its profit for the first half of its 1996-97 business year had more than tripled.
The German car maker also said it had signed a deal with Finland's Valmet Oy to help meet surging demand for its Boxster roadster.

Porsche, proclaiming it was back in the fast lane after hard times and weak sales in the early 1990s, said profit rose to 36 million marks ($22 million) in the six-month period to January 31 from 10.3 million ($6.25 million) in the same 1995-96 period.
Sales jumped 20 percent to 1.7 billion marks ($1.04 billion) as deliveries rose 25 percent to 12,800 vehicles, of which 3,150 were Boxsters, Porsche's first completely new car in two decades.

The six-month results prompted Porsche chief executive Wendelin Wiedeking to predict at the group's shareholder meeting that Porsche would top the 1995-96 business year sales of 2.8 billion marks ($1.7 billion) and net profit of 48.1 million marks ($29.3 billion).
Shares in Porsche gained sharply on the results, advancing 140 marks to 1,510 marks in midday bourse dealings, a 10 percent gain that clearly outpaced the broader German market.
Porsche said demand for the two-seat roadster was so strong that it planned to crank up production in a deal with Valmet to build at least 5,000 of the vehicles from autumn 1997.
Demand is predicted to keep rising only as the Boxster is offered into new markets, including February in America where Porsche wants to double its 1997 sales to 14,000 vehicles.
